lines.text: bats - are they really blind or just takin' a piss out of me?
What are you fishing for?
Fish.
This season, I'll be mostly wearing no vest and no pants neither...
I've gone vegetarian now. I mean, I know I had a sausage roll yesterday, but it's not really meat, is it, y'know? I mean, there's no animal called a "sausage".
Putting up a tent is very much like making love to a beautiful woman. Unzip the door, put up your pole, and slip into the old bag.

You know Ronnie Corbett? He's brilliant! But he's not really small. They made him look small to fit on telly. They did it with trick photography, which is brilliant. Only they call it special effects, and they're brilliant. Like in Terminator 2. Have you seen it? It's about this bloke who can turn into a puddle and back again. Fantastic! Aren't sequels brilliant? They're the same film but with a different number, like two or three. Even bad films are great, 'cause at least they try. In the future, all films will be brilliant. In fact, everything will be brilliant in the future, with cars on monorails, brilliant silvery costumes, food in pills and probably some special futurey can-opener. Fantastic! And everything will be done by computers. Aren't computers brilliant? They can do anything! Except play football. They'd be no good in goal, but they do everything else, virtually. I'n't virtual reality brilliant? It's exactly like reality, only you wear a hat! I tried it with me brother's crash helmet and I fell down the stairs. Aren't hospitals brilliant?
[repeated line]
A fe fe fe a fe fe fe, Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
Arseholes! Sorry I meant "Marvellous"...
What are you going to play for us today, Jackson?
Trumpet.
No, er, what tune?

[indignant]
Tune? This' jazz!

You a young mother, are you? That's the hardest job in the world is, innit, eh? The old motherin' game. Yeah, hardest game in the world. Yeah, I done it meself, see? Yeah. Thirty years, man and woman.
Self belief. I can do it. I can do it. I can do it, I can do it, I can really move from my head right down to my blue suede shoes. Isn't it? Rubettes, 1973? Marvellous.
Heey! My name's Dave Angel, eco warrior. Behind me there is my missus Shirley, and we haven't had sex for twelve years, which is fine because we got better things to do.
Chip? Take five - we need to reset the wire.
Set meself on fire? All right.
Of course, it wasn't always like that. I used to support... er? Manchester United. But then, you had to support them where I came from in... erm... Hampstead.
I opened my eyes and - by jingo! I realised I'd married three of 'em.
She was half woman, half fish. Terrible in the kitchen, but a bloody good swimmer.
Me? The 13th Duke of Wybourne? Here? In a sixth form girl's dormitory? At three o'clock in the morning? With my reputation? What were they thinking of?
I've ascertained the time of death as 9.15.
Have you really? What do you want, a biscuit?
Well, Ron Manager, once again the pace and the tempo of that first half totally dictated by the boy wonder, Ryan Giggs.
Cor, Ryan Giggs, you know? Giggsy, isn't it? Mmm? Giggsy-wiggsy? Mmm? Oh! Ryan-y Giggsy-wiggsy. Isn't it? You know, marvellous.
Is he the new George Best?

Is George Best the old Ryan Giggs? But Giggsy-wiggsy. Precocious talent, isn't he? Mmm? Ooh, got it all, you know? Speed, acceleration, sweet left foot, all the tricks - the dummy, the drop of the shoulder, the shimmy, nutmeg, jiggery-pokery, hocus pocus, abracadabra, I wanna reach out and grab ya. Steve Miller Band? Spin Doctors? Ooh, very similar.
Thank you, Ron. Now, Tommy, it's interesting to see the diamond formation being used again.

Diamond formation? Does anyone really know what that is? I mean, at least you knew where you were with Alf Ramsey's wingless wonders. You know? 4-4-2, 4-2-4, 4-3-3... 0898 654000, freephone double glazing?
You've lost me there, Ron. Not sure about that particular formation. But, Tommy, do we need structure? Look at the Brazilians.

Oh, those Brazilians, you know? Circa 1970? Broke the mould. Theory out the window. Free expression of football. Uncategorisable. Is that a word? It is now! You know? Far cry from small boys in the park, jumpers for goalposts. Rush goalie. Two at the back, three in the middle, four up front, one's gone home for his tea. Beans on toast? Possibly, don't quote me on that. Marvellous.
...thin layer of lemon curd...
Completely made out of rubber...
Blub, blub, blub, blub, blub and lays its eggs in your brain!
I punched him right on the nose!
Opened my eyes and, by George, realised I'd married three of them!
And I was feeling a little liverish!

[Out watercolour painting]
The rain is the sky's blood, pierced by the arrows of foolhardiness!
Sophocles!

[Holds up a glass of wine]
Ah, the grape! Dark... and black...
Johnny...
The blackness! The end! Where are we sleeping tonight, Mother? In Father's Grave!
I don't want to die! They wait for me in the forest...
Johnny?
The mounts are heavy and full of woe! I'm a fly! Trapped in a bottle of shadows!
My word look at that sky! We'll have to work like demons to get it down. Look at the contrasts, the whites, the black... You lock me in the cellar and feed me pins! Pins! Pins! Ew!
I think we'd better be getting home, now, Johnny.
What's for tea, Mother? Maggots on Toast?
They're here! They're here! They've landed on the Pier!
For God's sake, Paul, do you not realise! I'm having a nervous breakdown...

[a caravan site is on his slideshow]
In some dark corner of the human soul...
Oh you must have been there. Oh, it's quite, quite, quite, quite wonderful...

[the Rambling Hiker arrives at a petrol station somewhere in the middle of the countryside]
Hello! Hello, there! Hello! I was wondering if you could help me? My canteen is a bit low.
I see. You are lost and you want directions. Right. Now, you see this road here. You go up this road until you get to a tree. Lovely old tree!
No! you misunderstand me. I need some water for my canteen. Yes! It is very thirsty work hiking up and down the highways and byways.
And you'll be needing directions?
No! No! I am fully equipped. I know exactly where I am. I've never had to ask for directions. I am a fully experienced rambling hiker.
Are you sure about that?
Yes. I am quiet sure.
What about the end of that road, over there? Have you been down there?
I've just come from there. Yes.
But, that's no guarantee!
Well, I suppose not.
You better watch where are standing around her, boy. You might fall down a hole. Where would you be if you fell down a hole?
Well, yes.

What about a fog? Stuck in a hole in a fog? Stuck in a hole in a fog in the middle of the night - WITH AN OWL? Up a tree! Stuck in a hole in the middle of a night. Stuck down a hole with an owl! On your own behind the wall! Lovely old wall!
[the elderly petrol station attendant chases the rambling hiker away]
Stuck down a hole in the middle of the night with an owl! Stuck down a hole on your own in the middle of the night - WITH AN OWL!
But Genetically Modified Food? That's messing with Mother Nature's Ballbag.
Now look, I like you, but that's the language of the Snooker Hall!

[Rambling Hiker is walking along a road in the middle of the countryside. As Rambling Hiker stops to study his map. An old man disguised as a scarecrow walks over to him]
Are you lost?
No! No! No! I've studied the maps and I intend to walk over to that tree.
Lovely old tree.
Yes.
Are you a brave man?
No! No! I've done this sort of thing many times before. I have no fear.
You should have fear. There are plenty of dogs with real vengeance in their hearts, that lives down here.
I am a fully experienced rambling hiker. I always come prepared.
[Raises his horn]
One blast on this old friend will seriously stop any fierce dog from tangling with me. I simply raise my hand like this.
[Blows horn]
And it simply terrifies them.
What about owls? There are plenty of owls around here. And badgers? What about badgers?
I simply raise my hand like this. Lift my warning horn into my lips and
[Blows horn]
What about the slivering thing?
What?
A slivering thing. It might be death. Slivering things often are. What use would your fancy crimson hooter be then, hey? What about a slivering thing with an owl?
Thank you very much, I'll be on my way.
What about an eel? What about eels with mighty wingspan? Eels that can fly!
[Rambling Hiker blows his horn. The old man freezes. The Rambling Hiker continues walking. The old man stands still like a statue and walks after the Rambling Hiker]
